Cancer_types: All cancer types
Proposed_aetiology: Endogenous mutational process initiated by spontaneous deamination of 5-methylcytosine, correlates with aging.
Comments: NA

Cancer_types: 22 cancer types, most commonly in cervical and bladder cancers (usually in > 10% of samples)
Proposed_aetiology: Activity of AID/APOBEC family of cytidine deaminases (APOBEC1, APOBEC3A and/or APOBEC3B)
Comments: S2 is usually found in the same samples as S13. It has been proposed that activation of AID/APOBEC cytidine deaminases is due to viral infection, retrotransposon jumping or to tissue inflammation. Currently, there is limited evidence to support these hypotheses. A germline deletion polymorphism involving APOBEC3A and APOBEC3B is associated with the presence of large numbers of S2 and S13 mutations and with predisposition to breast cancer. Mutations of similar patterns to S2 and S13 are commonly found in the phenomenon of local hypermutation present in some cancers, known as kataegis, potentially implicating AID/APOBEC enzymes in this process as well.

Cancer_types: Breast, ovarian, and pancreatic cancers
Proposed_aetiology: Associated with failure of DNA double-strand break-repair by homologous recombination
Comments: Strongly associated with germline and somatic BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations in breast, pancreatic, and ovarian cancers. In pancreatic cancer, responders to platinum therapy usually exhibit S3 mutations

Cancer_types: Head and neck cancer, liver cancer, lung adenocarcinoma, lung squamous carcinoma, small cell lung carcinoma, oesophageal cancer
Proposed_aetiology: Associated with smoking and its profile is similar to the mutational pattern observed in experimental systems exposed to tobacco carcinogens (e.g., benzo[a]pyrene). S4 is likely due to tobacco mutagens
Comments: S29 is found in cancers associated with tobacco chewing and appears different from S4

Cancer_types: All cancer types
Proposed_aetiology: Unknown
Comments: Exhibits transcriptional strand bias for T>C substitutions at ApTpN context

Cancer_types: 17 cancer types, most common in colorectal and uterine cancers (usually in < 3% of samples)
Proposed_aetiology: Associated with defective DNA mismatch repair and is found in microsatellite unstable tumours
Comments: S6 is one of four mutational signatures associated with defective DNA mismatch repair and is often found in the same samples as S15, S20, S26

Cancer_types: Predominantly in skin cancers and in cancers of the lip categorized as head and neck or oral squamous cancers
Proposed_aetiology: Based on its prevalence in ultraviolet exposed areas and the similarity of the mutational pattern to that observed in experimental systems exposed to ultraviolet light S7 is likely due to ultraviolet light exposure
Comments: Signature 7 is associated with large numbers of CC>TT dinucleotide mutations at dipyrimidines. Additionally, Signature 7 exhibits a strong transcriptional strand-bias indicating that mutations occur at pyrimidines (viz., by formation of pyrimidine-pyrimidine photodimers) and these mutations are being repaired by transcription-coupled nucleotide excision repair.

Cancer_types: S8 has been found in breast cancer and medulloblastoma
Proposed_aetiology: Unknown
Comments: S8 exhibits weak strand bias for C>A substitutions and is associated with double nucleotide substitutions, notably CC>AA

Cancer_types: S9 has been found in chronic lymphocytic leukaemias and malignant B-cell lymphomas
Proposed_aetiology: S9 is characterized by a pattern of mutations that has been attributed to polymerase Î·, which is implicated with the activity of AID during somatic hypermutation
Comments: Chronic lymphocytic leukaemias that possess immunoglobulin gene hypermutation (IGHV-mutated) have elevated numbers of mutations attributed to S9 compared to those that do not have immunoglobulin gene hypermutation

Cancer_types: Found in six cancer types, notably colorectal and uterine cancer, usually generating huge numbers of mutations in small subsets of samples
Proposed_aetiology: It has been proposed that the mutational process underlying this signature is altered activity of the error-prone polymerase POLE. The presence of large numbers of S10 mutations is associated with recurrent POLE somatic mutations, viz., Pro286Arg and Val411Leu
Comments: S10 exhibits strand bias for C>A mutations at TpCpT context and T>G mutations at TpTpT context

Cancer_types: Melanoma and glioblastoma
Proposed_aetiology: S11 exhibits a mutational pattern resembling that of alkylating agents. Patient histories have revealed an association between treatments with the alkylating agent temozolomide and S11 mutations
Comments: S11 exhibits a strong transcriptional strand-bias for C>T substitutions indicating that mutations occur on guanine and that these mutations are effectively repaired by transcription-coupled nucleotide excision repair

Cancer_types: Liver cancer
Proposed_aetiology: Unknown
Comments: Strong transcriptional strand-bias for T>C substitutions (contributes a small percentage (< 20%) of mutations observed in a liver cancer sample)

Cancer_types: 22 cancer tyeps, most common in cervical and bladder cancers (usually in > 10% of samples)
Proposed_aetiology: S13 has been attributed to activity of the AID/APOBEC family of cytidine deaminases converting cytosine to uracil. On the basis of similarities in the sequence context of cytosine mutations caused by APOBEC enzymes in experimental systems, a role for APOBEC1, APOBEC3A and/or APOBEC3B in human cancer appears more likely than for other members of the family. Signature 13 causes predominantly C>G mutations. This may be due to generation of abasic sites after removal of uracil by base excision repair and replication over these abasic sites by REV1
Comments: S2 is usually found in the same samples as S13. It has been proposed that activation of AID/APOBEC cytidine deaminases is due to viral infection, retrotransposon jumping or to tissue inflammation. Currently, there is limited evidence to support these hypotheses. A germline deletion polymorphism involving APOBEC3A and APOBEC3B is associated with the presence of large numbers of S2 and S13 mutations and with predisposition to breast cancer. Mutations of similar patterns to S2 and S13 are commonly found in the phenomenon of local hypermutation present in some cancers, known as kataegis, potentially implicating AID/APOBEC enzymes in this process as well

Cancer_types: Four uterine cancers and a single adult low-grade glioma sample
Proposed_aetiology: Unknown
Comments: Generates very high numbers of somatic mutations (>200 mutations per MB) in all samples in which it has been observed

Cancer_types: Several stomach cancers and a single small cell lung carcinoma
Proposed_aetiology: Associated with defective DNA mismatch repair
Comments: S15 is one of four mutational signatures associated with defective DNA mismatch repair and is often found in the same samples as S6, S20, S26

Cancer_types: Liver cancer
Proposed_aetiology: Unknown
Comments: Exhibits an extremely strong transcriptional strand bias for T>C mutations at ApTpN context, with T>C mutations occurring almost exclusively on the transcribed strand

Cancer_types: Oesophagus cancer, breast cancer, liver cancer, lung adenocarcinoma, B-cell lymphoma, stomach cancer, melanoma
Proposed_aetiology: Unknown
Comments: NA

Cancer_types: Neuroblastoma (some breast and stomach)
Proposed_aetiology: Unknown
Comments: NA

Cancer_types: Pilocytic astrocytoma
Proposed_aetiology: Unkonwn
Comments: NA

Cancer_types: Stomach and breast cancers
Proposed_aetiology: S20 is believed to be associated with defective DNA mismatch repair
Comments: S20 is one of four mutational signatures associated with defective DNA mismatch repair and is often found in the same samples as S6, S15, and S26

Cancer_types: Stomach cancers
Proposed_aetiology: Unknown
Comments: S21 is found only in four samples all generated by the same sequencing centre. The mutational pattern of S21 is somewhat similar to the one of S26. Additionally, S21 is found only in samples that also have S15 and S20. As such, S21 is probably also related to microsatellite unstable tumours

Cancer_types: Urothelial (renal pelvis) carcinoma and liver cancers
Proposed_aetiology: S22 has been found in cancer samples with known exposures to aristolochic acid. Additionally, the pattern of mutations exhibited by the signature is consistent with the one previous observed in experimental systems exposed to aristolochic acid
Comments: S22 exhibits a very strong transcriptional strand bias for T>A mutations indicating adenine damage that is being repaired by transcription-coupled nucleotide excision repair, very high mutational burden in urothelial carcinoma; however, its mutational burden is much lower in liver cancers

Cancer_types: Single liver cancer sample
Proposed_aetiology: Unknown
Comments: Transcriptional strand bias for C>T mutations

Cancer_types: A subset of liver cancers
Proposed_aetiology: S24 has been found in cancer samples with known exposures to aflatoxin. Additionally, the pattern of mutations exhibited by the signature is consistent with that previous observed in experimental systems exposed to aflatoxin
Comments: S24 exhibits a very strong transcriptional strand bias for C>A mutations indicating guanine damage that is being repaired by transcription-coupled nucleotide excision repair

Cancer_types: Hodgkin lymphomas
Proposed_aetiology: Unkonwn
Comments: Transcriptional strand bias for T>A mutations

Cancer_types: Breast cancer, cervical cancer, stomach cancer and uterine carcinoma
Proposed_aetiology: S26 is believed to be associated with defective DNA mismatch repair
Comments: S26 is one of four mutational signatures associated with defective DNA mismatch repair and is often found in the same samples as S6, S15 and S20

Cancer_types: A subset of kidney clear cell carcinomas
Proposed_aetiology: Unknown
Comments: Strong transcriptional strand bias for T>A mutations. S27 is associated with high numbers of small (shorter than 3bp) insertions and deletions at mono/polynucleotide repeats

Cancer_types: A subset of stomach cancers
Proposed_aetiology: Unknown
Comments: NA

Cancer_types: Gingivo-buccal oral squamous cell carcinoma
Proposed_aetiology: S29 has been found in cancer samples from individuals with a tobacco chewing habit
Comments: S29 exhibits transcriptional strand bias for C>A mutations indicating guanine damage that is most likely repaired by transcription-coupled nucleotide excision repair. S29 is also associated with CC>AA dinucleotide substitutions

Cancer_types: A small subset of breast cancers
Proposed_aetiology: Unknown
Comments: NA
